item.description:
Report E-2025040166

Identified by scraper @ 2025-05-06T01:06:02+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-04-07
  • City: MELBOURNE
  • State: FL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On April 7, 2025, one (1) 5-gallon pail of UN1903 was damaged and released approximately three (3) gallons of product to the trailer interior and pavement beneath. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from American Safety (AS) to remediate the site. The crew utilized absorbents and hand tools to clear the impacted areas. All impacted materials and the damaged pail were containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum for disposal.

  • Description: On April 3, 2025, one (1) 5-gallon pail of UN1814 was crushed in transit and released approximately five (5) gallons of product to the trailer interior and pavement below. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from American Safety (AS) to remediate the site. The damaged pail was collected in one (1) 55-gallon drum. Absorbents and neutralizing agents were utilized to remediate the site. All impacted materials were containerized in one (1) additional 55-gallon drum for disposal.

item.title: Report E-2025040114
item.description:
Report E-2025040114

Identified by scraper @ 2025-05-06T01:06:02+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-09
  • City: LEHIGH ACRES
  • State: FL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: LEE COUNTY MOSQUITO CONTROL DISTRICT
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: The driver thought that the meter had a tenth section, so instead of loading 77 gallons, he reached 189 (thinking this equated to 18.9 gallons). At this point, fuel started to appear and the pump was shut off and containment operations commenced. Because we are required to report within 15 minutes, I estimated that 100 gallons was spilled for the initial report. Our spill response crew absorbed and recovered all spilled fuel with appropriate PPE and appropriately cleaned the airport ramp fueling area. Jet fuel was transferred in order to maintain the air space in the tanker including any recovered fuel which did not reach the ramp ground back into the jet fuel tank of origin (through appropriate filtration). After further calculations, beyond the initial 15 minutes, we believe that between 30 - 50 gallons were spilled before being absorbed and appropriately being disposed of at an approved disposal facility.
